event: Earliest evidence of human habitation by Guanahatabey and other indigenous peoples.
Taíno people, an Arawakan-speaking group, dominate most of the island.
Christopher Columbus lands on Cuba during his first voyage to the Americas.
Spanish begin colonization under Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar; indigenous resistance crushed.
First recorded importation of enslaved Africans to Cuba.
British capture Havana during the Seven Years’ War.
Havana returned to Spain in exchange for Florida under the Treaty of Paris.
Ten Years' War begins, first major Cuban war for independence from Spain.
Ten Years' War ends in failure; Spain retains control.
José Martí leads renewed fight for independence; Cuban War of Independence begins.
Spanish-American War leads to U.S. intervention; Spain loses control of Cuba.
Cuba formally gains independence but remains under U.S. influence via the Platt Amendment.
Sergeants' Revolt overthrows President Gerardo Machado; rise of Fulgencio Batista.
Batista seizes power in a military coup.
Fidel Castro leads failed attack on Moncada Barracks; beginning of Cuban Revolution.
Castro and revolutionary forces overthrow Batista; establish communist state.
Bay of Pigs Invasion by U.S.-backed exiles fails to topple Castro.
Cuban Missile Crisis brings U.S. and USSR to the brink of nuclear war.
Mariel boatlift: over 100,000 Cubans emigrate to the U.S.
Collapse of Soviet Union triggers economic crisis known as the 'Special Period'.
Fidel Castro hands power to his brother Raúl Castro due to illness.
U.S. and Cuba restore diplomatic relations after decades of hostility.
Miguel Díaz-Canel becomes president, succeeding Raúl Castro.
Mass protests erupt over economic hardship and lack of freedoms.
